title: DNA Replication Leading and Lagging Strands

content.question:
Figure 1 depicts a simplified model of a replication bubble.

Figure 1. <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></math> replication bubble.

Which of the following best explains how this model illustrates <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> replication of both strands as a replication fork moves?

choices.label: <math alttext="Roman numeral 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Roman numeral 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are synthesized continuously in the <math alttext="5 prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>5</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="3 prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>3</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> direction.

<math alttext="Roman numeral 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> and <math alttext="Roman numeral 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> are synthesized in segments in the <math alttext="3 prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>3</mn><mo>′</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="5 prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mn>5</mn><mo>′</mo></mrow></mstyle></math> direction.

<math alttext="Roman numeral 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is synthesized continuously in the <math alttext="5 prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>5</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="3 prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>3</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> direction, and <math alttext="Roman numeral 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is synthesized in segments in the <math alttext="5 prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="3 prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>3</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> direction.

<math alttext="Roman numeral 2" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>II</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is synthesized in segments after <math alttext="D N A" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>DNA </mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> polymerase is released from synthesizing strand <math alttext="Roman numeral 4" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mtext>IV</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math>.

content.answer: <math alttext="Roman numeral 1" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mi>I</mi></mrow></mstyle></mrow></mstyle></math> is synthesized continuously in the <math alttext="5 prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>5</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="3 prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>3</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> direction, and <math alttext="Roman numeral 3" overflow="scroll"><mstyle mathvariant="normal"><mrow><mtext>III</mtext></mrow></mstyle></math> is synthesized in segments in the <math alttext="5 prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mn>5</mn></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> to <math alttext="3 prime" overflow="scroll"><mstyle><mrow><msup><mrow><mtext>3</mtext></mrow><mrow><mo>′</mo></mrow></msup></mrow></mstyle></math> direction.

skill.text: 2.B: Explain relationships between characteristics of biological models in both theoretical and applied contexts.
